awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Physics at Miami University
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site in physics at the Miami University Oxford Campus.  Ten students will be supported for ten weeks of summer research each year in topics from biophysics, optics and quantum optics/quantum information, condensed matter physics, and physics education research.  The goals of the site are to provide (i) mentored research opportunities for a diverse group of students; (ii) professional development topics; (iii) interactions with other students and faculty on a professional and social level. The overarching goal is to promote physics as a professional choice and send more talented students to graduate school in STEM fields.

Student mentoring will take place on multiple levels. REU students work in groups with one or two undergraduate students and a Masters level graduate student. Working groups will meet regularly with the mentors and discuss progress, or solve problems encountered.  The site will enhance the research and professional skills of the participants and the students will meet on a regular basis to discuss professional development topics. Through these activities, the site is training the next generation of physicists.This site is supported by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of that grant was to promote physics as a professional choice and send more talented students to graduate school in STEM fields. In particular, our program provided mentored research opportunities to a diverse group of students who are underrepresented in physics; professional development; and interactions with other students and faculty on a social level.

 

Over three summers we hosted 29 students. 15 of them were women, 2 were Black, 2 were Latinx, 11 were Pell Grant recipients, and 13 were first-generation college students.

 

All of these students did closely mentored research; every tenure-track and tenured professor submitted. Everyone presented their work in a symposium at the end of each summer, and as of now one student has published a paper, 2 have submitted a paper recently and 15 have given talks on their work.

 

Students also participated in a professional development series. The topics were:

  • Your role as physicists in the STEM workplace.
  • Ethics quandaries you might encounter, including a presentation from the Director of Research Ethics and Integrity
  • Diversity in our community.
  • Graduate school, including a presentation from the Director of Graduate Admission and a panel of PhD students from cognate departments
  • A visit to Wright Patterson Air Force Base, a national center for STEM research
  • Writing for a scientific audience
  • Preparing an oral presentation for a conference
  • Preparing a poster presentation for a conference

 

In addition, they had plenty of time to get to know each other and the undergraduate and graduate students from our own university during the summers. Before the first week was out, students went on a low ropes course designed by our university’s Outdoor Pursuit Center to improve communication, teamwork, and confidence, and by the end of that activity they all knew each other’s names.

 

They also spent time together doing many other things:

  • Weekly volleyball games
  • Watching movies
  • Dinner at the house of the PI, co-PI, and department chair
  • Bowling
  • Fourth of July festivities
  • Trips to local lakes for swimming

 

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2022
Modified by: Jennifer M Blue
